text: Deadline for the machine recount is November 15th at 3pm. Deadline for the manual recount is November 18th at noon. Deadline for remaining overseas/military ballots, which can be counted in the meantime, is November 16th (they must be postmarked on or before November 6th. (6)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Because DeSantis is leading Gillum by 33,684 votes, a margin of 0.410%, his race will not be manually recounted—unless the automatic recount is so dramatic that it reduces the margin to 0.25% or below. Scott's lead, however, is 12,562—0.154%—so a manual recount is guaranteed. (5)
author: charlescwcooke

text: An "overvote" can be more complicated, as canvassing boards are, within reason, permitted to determine voter intent. If there is a faint mark in one candidate's oval but a full mark in another, that might plausibly be counted. A total mess, by contrast, will not be counted. (4)
author: charlescwcooke

text: An "undervote" is almost never counted. If a voter declines to vote for a particular office, that's his choice and there's nothing anyone can do. As such, an "undervote" will only be counted if, say, the optical machine has made an error and failed to pick up a vote. (3)
author: charlescwcooke

text: A "manual recount" does not mean every vote is counted by hand. Rather, it involves canvassing boards checking every "undervote" and "overvote." An "overvote" is when a voter makes more choices than allowed; an "undervote" is when a voter makes no choice, or too few choices. (2)
author: charlescwcooke

text: A few definitions. An "automatic recount" is required for any race with a margin under 0.5%. It involves feeding all the ballots back through the voting machines—including reconstructed damaged ballots. If the new result yields a winning margin over 0.25 the election is over. (1)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Which is to say that, as it stands, Ron DeSantis is the next governor of Florida, and, barring some catastrophic errors in tabulation, or some remarkably creative lawyering, Rick Scott is Florida's next Senator. But it's Florida, so . . . (12/12)
author: charlescwcooke

text: That would be a small enough lead that a recount could potentially change the result. But to get to that point we have to make a lot of pro-Democrat assumptions, and to assume facts not in evidence. It seems unlikely to me that either of these results is going to change. (11)
author: charlescwcooke

text: If we subtract the number of votes for Senate in Broward from the number of votes for Governor, we get 24,992. Assuming that these votes go as did the others, that adds just over 9,000 votes for Nelson. (It doesn't affect DeSantis.) Which leaves Scott with a lead of ~200. (10)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Which brings us, finally, to Marc Elias's theory that the machines in Broward have undercounted the Senate line on the ballot by around 25,000 ballots. I doubt this—and Broward says it's not correct—but, arguendo, let's add it to our previous assumptions. Then what? (9)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Even in that generous scenario, DeSantis keeps a lead of 30,484, while Scott keeps a lead of 9,362. That means Gillum would need 15,242 votes to flip, and Nelson would need 4,681. That seems unlikely—although nothing is impossible. (8)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Remember, that’s a generous estimate because we’re assuming every single outstanding overseas ballot comes in. But, for the sake of argument, let’s make it *more* generous, and assume these votes are twice as Democratic as has been the case thus far. Let's make it ~3,200. (7)
author: charlescwcooke

text: That would yield a DeSantis lead of ~32,000, and a Scott lead of ~11,000. Which would require the recounts to flip, *net*, 16,000 votes to Gillum and 5,500 votes to Nelson. (6)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Given that voters with no party also vote, the best we can do is apply known military registration rates to military data, and apply the results in each county thus far to the county data. If we do this, we get a net increase for both Nelson and Gillum of ~1600 votes. (5)
author: charlescwcooke

text: For the sake of argument, though, let's assume they're all returned—every last one. From what I can gather, we’re looking at ~5,000 military ballots, and then ~15,000 others from around the state. (4)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Around 20,000 overseas/military ballots have yet to be returned. Deadline for their return is the 16th. In reality, a lot of these will never be returned, will arrive too late, or will be rejected. (3)
author: charlescwcooke

text: There are now two things left to do statewide: First, count yet-to-arrive overseas/military ballots; second, proceed to those mandatory recounts. All being equal, neither step looks as if it'll be enough for either Gillum or Nelson. (2)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Florida update. All 67 counties have now reported, and we have an unofficial vote tally. As it stands, DeSantis leads Gillum by 33,684, and Scott leads Nelson by 12,562. That will precipitate an automatic recount for DeSantis, and a manual recount for Scott. (1)

author: charlescwcooke

text: You can't "see" someone "blackout drunk." It doesn't mean "really drunk." "Blackout drunk" means you don't remember what happened while you were that drunk. It's a form of amnesia—and, at this remove, impossible to prove either way. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackout_(drug-related_amnesia) …

author: charlescwcooke

text: We've been asking him about it for the last hour, and he's convinced. His story is consistent. He knows exactly what he thinks happened. And the best part is that he's not remotely scared. He keeps going and sitting on the bed, and pointing to where it happened. (5)
author: charlescwcooke

text:
As casually as can be, he repeated it. "There was a beast and a lion on the bed. They pushed me out." 
"A beast and a lion?"
"Yes."
"What noise does a lion make?"
He made his hands into claws. "ROAR!"
"And a lion was on your bed?"
"Yes."
"And a beast?"
"Yes." (4)
author: charlescwcooke

text:
"You fell out in the dark?" I asked him. "Yes," he said. "Well, it's a new bed," I said. "Yes," he agreed. Then he looked grave: "There was a beast and a lion on the bed, and they pushed me out, and I got a boo boo."

"Sorry, what?" (3)
author: charlescwcooke

text: Surprisingly, that was the last of it. He woke up this morning at the usual time, I went and got him, and we sat on the couch and chatted for a bit as the sun came up. After a little while, he told me that he "fell out of the bed in the dark" and got "a boo boo." I agreed. (2)
